Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Welcome to the first-quarter 2018 Arista Networks financial results earnings conference call. [Operator instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded and will be available for replay some Investor Relations section at the Arista website following this call. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Charles Yager, director of investor relations.
Sir, you may begin.
Charles Yager -- Director of Investor Relations
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. With me on today's call are Jayshree Ullal, Arista Networks' president and chief executive officer, and Ita Brennan, Arista's chief financial officer. This afternoon, Arista Networks issued a press release announcing the release of its fiscal first quarter 2018.
If you'd like a copy of the release, you can access it online at the company's website. During the course of this conference call, Arista Networks' management will make forward-looking statements, including those relating to our financial outlook for the second quarter of the 2018 fiscal year, industry innovations, our market opportunity, and the impact of litigation, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties that we discuss in detail in our documents filed with the SEC, specifically in the most recent Form 10-K and which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by these statements. These forward-looking statements apply as of today, and you should not rely on them as we presenting our views in the future. We undertake no obligation to update these statements after this call.

Also, please note that certain financial measures we use on this call are expressed on a non-GAAP basis and have been adjusted exclude certain charges. We have provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures in our earnings press release. With that, I will turn the call over to Jayshree.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Charles. Thank you, everyone, for joining us this afternoon for our first-quarter of 2018 earnings call. I am pleased to report that we had a good quarter, given the normal seasonality. We demonstrated a predictable profitable growth with non-GAAP revenue of $472.5 million, as we grew more than 40% year over year.
Non-GAAP earnings per share was $1.66 with services contributing 13.7% of overall sales. From a geographic perspective, our customers in the Americas contributed 67% of the total revenue, while the rest of the international theaters [Inaudible] progressed steadily in the quarter. We delivered non-GAAP gross margins of 64.4% in a highly dynamic and competitive industry. Our top 10 customers included four out of five verticals.
Cloud titans contributed strongly in Q1 and ranked as our No. 1 vertical, followed by enterprises at No. 2. Service providers and cloud specialized providers pretty much tied at No.
3, followed by financial. Our new-customer acquisition continues to be healthy, as we exceeded 5,000 cumulative customers this quarter, and we continued to perform well with FlexRoute, our routing license, and CloudVision software customers as well. At Arista, we have always embraced open networking trends by designing our platforms with merchants silicon diversity, while using modern software to form l differentiated cloud networks. On March 29, Arista introduced the latest data center fixed leaf models based on Broadcom's Trident 3 and Tomahawk 2 silicon.
Arista 7050X3 and 7260X3 platforms run on the single EOS software image and CloudVision for operational consistency. Some of the key innovations include intelligent buffering and automated network load balancing, path and latency monitoring, new protocols such as segment routing in a fully featured VXLAN stack, high availability with hidden software upgrades, low-power 25-gig 100-gig fixed system that are double the capacity of the predecessors, and cloud-scale performance with 12.8 terabit scale and 4.2 billion packets per second of packet forwarding. On OCP's event in March 2018 in San Jose, Arista demonstrated disaggregated EOS via collaboration with two key cloud partners, Facebook with Wedge 100 and Microsoft with SONiC. As many of you may know, we began our Microsoft journey back in 2015 or '16 with SAI, Switch Abstraction Interface, via cold contributions to this initiative.
This year, Arista and Microsoft expanded the sonic initiative across the flagship Arista 7500 as the only modular chassis supporting Microsoft Management stack. Arista also supports EOS and containerized EOS on Facebook's open Wedge 100. This allows customization of scripts for automating network operations flows. And in both these cases, Arista's advanced EOS SDK is demonstrated in full action.
This quarter we also participated in routing interoperability at the MPLS + SDN + NFV World Congress event in Paris. We're gratified to be recognized for the first time in the [Inaudible] for hardware platforms and SDN as a leader with a top score in both strategy and current offering in Q1 2018. We're also proud to be recognized as one of the top 10 employers in the Bay Area's Best Places to Work in the large employee category, ranked No. 9 out of 130 eligible companies.
As I look at Q1 2018 and reflect on our start, I am pleased with our performance and the trajectory ahead. In particular, we are now well beyond the overhead and delays of customer certifications that we have been experiencing during the past three quarters, having successfully completed most of the certification. And in light of the recent IPC suspensions on the remedial orders of the 668 patent as well as the expiration of the 577 patent on June 30, we pretty much expect to return to normalcy in the second half 2018 with respect to 945. And so, with that, I'd like to turn it over to Ita, our chief financial officer, for Q1 2018 financial details, Ita?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Thanks, Jayshree, and good afternoon. This analysis of our Q1 results and our guidance for Q2 '18 is based on a non-GAAP and includes all non-cash stock-based compensation impacts and legal costs associated with the ongoing lawsuits. A full reconciliation of our selected GAAP to non-GAAP results is provided in our earnings release. Total revenues in Q1 were $472.5 million, up 41% year over year and above our guidance of $450 million to $468 million.
We were pleased with the overall demand in the quarter, with particular strength from our cloud titan vertical. Service revenues represented approximately 13.7% of revenues, up slightly from prior quarters. International revenue for the quarter came in at $157 million, or 33% of total revenue, consistent with the prior period. While some of this continued strength in international mix was related to deployments by our U.S.
cloud titan customers, we also experienced healthy growth from our in-region international businesses in the period. Overall gross margin in Q1 was 64.4%, down from 65.9% last quarter but about the midpoint of our guidance of 63% to 65%. This reflected unanticipated return to a more typical customer mix for the first quarter. Operating expenses for the quarter were $137.4 million, down from $139.4 million last quarter.
R&D spending came in at $91.4 million, or 19.3% of revenue, down from $96 million last quarter, with reduced prototype spending offset by headcount additions. Sales and marketing expense was $36.2 million, or 7.7% of revenue, up from $33.5 million last quarter, reflecting growth in headcount. Our operating income for the quarter was $166.7 million, or 35.3% of revenue. Other income and expense for the quarter was a favorable $4.2 million, and our effective tax rate was 21.5%.
The higher-than-anticipated tax rate reflects updated guidance in relation to the recently adopted tax act. This resulted in net income for the quarter of $134.1 million, or 28.4%. Our diluted share number for the quarter was 80.7 million shares, resulting in a diluted earnings-per-share number of $1.66, up 79% in the prior year. Legal expenses associated with the ongoing lawsuits came in $7.1 million for the quarter and are excluded from our non-GAAP results.
Now, turning to the balance sheet. Cash, cash-equivalents, and investments ended the quarter at approximately $1.7 billion. We generated $195.5 million of cash from operations in the March quarter, which reflects strong net income performance combined with overall improvements in working capital requirements. DSOs came in at 39 days, down from 49 days in Q4, reflecting the timing of billings and collections in the quarter.
Inventory turns were 2.2 times, up from 1.8 times in Q4. Inventory decreased to $268.1 million in the quarter, down from $306.2 million in the prior period. This reflects reductions in both raw materials and finished goods as we continued optimize on supply chain. In addition, we maintained further $24 million of inventory deposits recorded in other assets, compared to $34 million last quarter.
Our total deferred-revenue balance was $456.1 million, down from $515.3 million in Q4. The product deferred revenue declined by approximately $50 million in the quarter, with customers completing many of their 945-related qualification. In addition, as part of our adoption of ASU 606, reclassified approximately $19 million of software-related deferred revenue to other contract liabilities on the balance sheet. As we go forward, you should expect lower levels of product deferred revenue, given the relative maturity of the R-Series platform, completion of any remaining 945-related certifications and the adoption of ASU 606.
As a reminder, any such decline in deferred product revenue is not in and of itself an indication of change in the underlying demand trends of the business. Accounts payable days were 38 days, up from 30 days in Q4, reflecting the timing of inventory receipts from payments. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $6.3 million. Now turning to our outlook for the second quarter and beyond.
We are pleased with the momentum of the business in the first quarter with the strong demand, particularly from our cloud customers. As we look forward to the remainder of 2018, we believe that we are well-positioned to benefit from the continuing growth in cloud networking across our customer base. Given some tough 2017 comparables, we believe that the current consensus for the balance of the year, which calls for year-over-year growth in the mid-20% range, remains relevant. Our gross margin guidance from the second quarter of 62% to 64% reflects an anticipated mix toward cloud revenues in the quarter.
We now expect our go-forward non-GAAP tax rate to be in the range of 21% to 22%, reflecting further guidance of elements of the recently adopted tax act. With this as a backdrop, our guidance for the second quarter, which is based on non-GAAP results and excludes any noncash stock-based compensation impact and any legal costs associated with the ongoing lawsuits is as follows; revenues of approximately $500 million to $514 million, gross margin of approximately 62% to 64%, operating margin of approximately 32% to 34%. Our effective tax rate is expected to be approximately 21.5% with diluted shares of approximately $81 million. Please note that based on our current outlook, we expect cost associated of the ongoing lawsuits to be approximately $6 million for the quarter.
I will now turn the call back to Charles. Charles?
Charles Yager -- Director of Investor Relations
Thank you, Ita. We are now going to move to the Q&A portion of the Arista earnings call. Due to time constraints, I'd like to request that everyone please limit themselves to a single question.

Questions and Answers:
Operator
[Operator instructions] Your first question comes from Rod Hall with Goldman Sachs. Your line is open.
Rod Hall -- Goldman Sachs -- Analyst
Yeah, Hi, guys. Thanks for taking the question. I guess I wanted to focus on the 945 certifications and just ask a couple of important questions around that. No.1, is all the deferred revenue associated with those now released or is there still some deferred-revenue balance associated with those certifications? I want to be clear on that.
And then, my bigger question is, you guys had called out some of the project-oriented delays as a result of those certifications. Are those projects back online now, or are you still ramping back to normal spending with some of those customers that were waiting to certify? Thanks.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Rod. I'll take the second one first and then hand off to Ita on the deferred piece. So I think we, having now completed majority of our certifications -- and if you recall, I was explaining how some of the complex use cases took time -- so we feel pretty good about that. In 2018, we're pretty much now starting to look at the impact of certifications to be very minimal in Q2 and virtually nonexistent in the second half.
So we're actually back to new projects now. So the worst is behind us. Ita?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes. I'll just take care of your first question, Rod. I think there is still some 945 certification-related deferred there. It's small.
And then, there is some other unrelated stuff just normal kind of feature delivery type deferred that's in the balance sheet. So that number is not going to be much smaller and it will rotate based on features and value of features as we make commitments in particular contracts going forward.
Rod Hall -- Goldman Sachs -- Analyst
And I wonder -- just a follow-up. I wonder -- could you guys comment a little bit of what you're seeing with respect to AI workloads and spending there? And do you think you have the majority of networking in that market? Or do you find if there's quite a bit of competition around? Just curious how that's going?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
So I think the whole AI space is very, very exciting. The -- It's clearly in very early stages. We have a -- in fact, just two weeks ago, we were on a roadshow and with our partners Invidia, and storage partner, Pure. And what I would say to that is clearly the -- importance of AI is to reduce cycle time.
And that has a profound impact on the bandwidth performance, capacity, and latency of networking. So we derive an indirect benefit as a result of the large amounts of GPU. But still very early stages, I would say in experimental stages.
Rod Hall -- Goldman Sachs -- Analyst
Great. OK. Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks.
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
You're welcome
Operator
Your next question comes from Jim Suva with Citi. Your line is open.
Jim Suva -- Citi -- Analyst
Thanks very much. Given a lot of the news about privacy concerns and geopolitical trade wars and tensions, such like that, have you seen any change in behavior to your cloud spending or any of your customers either in a positive or pausing manner? What I'm getting at is, are they looking at putting in some more of your product because of these concerns or some less, or waiting to figure it out, and especially with the trade wars?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Oh, wow. Thanks, Jim, that's a heavy-duty question. I'm going to start to answer it, but I won't do enough justice. So Anshul Sadana, our chief customer officer, who is much more intimate with the cloud, will give you more details.
When you look at the whole security and privacy space. I think there is an element of how we work closely with our security vendors, an element of isolation and segmentation, and a strong element of audit compliance and encryption. And particularly since the cloud vendors are deploying a lot of data centers, the encryption and the ownership of the fiber becomes a big deal. Anshul, you want to say some more?
Anshul Sadana -- Chief Customer Officer
Absolutely, Jayshree. The data protection in the cloud is very relevant, not so much with respect to the trade wards, but with things like GDPR or any local laws that exist. So when you look at the cloud companies, the regions they're building out, you'll see that some of the regions are smaller and localized within Western Europe or one-off countries. That's all the impact that we see.
And that's all part of cloud business that we're already in.
Jim Suva -- Citi -- Analyst
Great. Thank you so much for the details. It's appreciated. Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Jim
Operator
Your next question comes from Srini Pajjuri from Macquarie. Your line is open.
Srini Pajjuri -- Macquarie Research -- Analyst
Two questions, Ita. You mentioned mid-20% growth is what you're comfortable for the year. Obviously, you grew 40% in Q1. Does this mean your second half, you're assuming some sort of deceleration from the mid-20% or do you expect that to be within the ballpark? And then just one clarification.
You said ASU 606 had, like, $19 million impact on deferred revenues. Did that help you in terms of revenue in the quarter? Thank you.
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes. So on the first one. I think the commentary was that for the balance of the year, for the remainder of the year, we would say we -- we think the mid-20s is a reasonable way to think about the growth rate, right, but not incorporating the Q1 growth rate. And then on the ASU 606.
It's really a balance-sheet reclass. It's kind of on a technicality where we have some prepaid subscriptions and we're required to record it as a contract liability as opposed to deferred revenue. So it's really a relocation on balance sheet from deferred to other contract liabilities. So not flowing through the P&L.
Srini Pajjuri -- Macquarie Research -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Your next question comes from Jeff Kvaal with Nomura. Your line is open.
Jeff Kvaal -- Nomura Instinet -- Analyst
Yes. Thanks very much. We've been hit by a raft of headlines from the cloud spenders over the last week or so talking about big beats in their capex. It sounds like that is a pretty closely tied to what is going on in the underlying business.
So capex for them ought to be growing faster in 2018 than it grew in 2017. It looks like you all are set to grow a little slower in 2018 versus last year. Can you help us bridge that gap? I understand from quarter to quarter things fluctuate, but over the course of the year, we would like to think that things would balance out a little bit. Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, certainly, Jeff. As you know, cloud titans do have seasonal spending. And we have enjoyed a very strong partnership with many of them and continue to. Our heritage is undoubtedly, and our forecast, and our past, our present, and our future is very much tied to cloud networking for all types of customers.
I think what you should take away from this is, while we have a great deal of visibility to the near future, which is one or two quarters, their spending for the entire year or subsequent quarters involves a lot of moves and shifts and networking is still a very small piece of their capex. So we continued to understand the use cases. Anshul and the team is very intimately involved, and we have no reason to believe that there aren't technically or businesswise a strong partnership. But we will only know more, say, for Q4 around Q2 or Q3.
So therefore it's really hard to predict and we try not to, since sometimes they don't know, and therefore we don't know, either. Anshul, you want to add anything more to that?
Anshul Sadana -- Chief Customer Officer
Absolutely. I want to remind everyone, we have discussed in the past. For the cloud companies, a data center buildout or [Inaudible] buildout, is a two- to three-year project. And when the networking components land and we see the product bookings and revenue does not exactly in the same month the same quarter.
The lag would be as much as 18 months for the bigger regions. That's why it's very hard for us to forecast.
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes, but I'd remind you, Jeff, that cloud was strong from a momentum -- from a demand perspective in Q1. So it's typically strong and we saw that again this quarter.
Jeff Kvaal -- Nomura Instinet -- Analyst
OK. Thank you. And maybe to probe on that little bit you talked about a --
Charles Yager -- Director of Investor Relations
We're limiting Jeff to one question, if you don't mind.
Jeff Kvaal -- Nomura Instinet -- Analyst
Oh, you got me, Charles. You got me. Go ahead.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Jeff.
Operator
Your next question comes from Alex Kurtz KeyBanc. Your line is open.
Steven Enders -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Hi, guys. This is Steve Enders on for Alex. I was wondering if you guys had seen any change in mix of top-of-rack switches and Spine within your webscale customers over the past few years or how that's trended? And how does that also compare in the service-provider segment?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
We don't see any appreciable change. Obviously, the Spine and routing has given us more use cases in the cloud and service provider, but the lease gives us a lot of ports. So overall, not much difference.
Steven Enders -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Steve.
Operator
Your next question comes from Paul Silverstein with Cowen and Company. Your line is open.
Paul Silverstein -- Cowen & Company -- Analyst
I'll keep it simple [Inaudible]
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Paul, you're sounding very muffled.
Yes. We can't hear you, Paul.
Paul Silverstein -- Cowen & Company -- Analyst
[Inaudible]
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
We can't hear you. Can we skip him and go to the next?
Charles Yager -- Director of Investor Relations
Yeah. Can we come back to you, Paul? We need better quality.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
We can't hear you. You're very muffled. Let's get -- let's fix that line, and we'll come back to you.
Operator
Your next question comes from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer. Your line is open.
Ittai Kidron -- Oppenheimer & Company -- Analyst
Thanks. And good quarter out of the gate, guys -- I guess, ladies and guy. Help me think about when you talk about the mid-20s for remainder of the year including the second quarter. Can you help me think on a -- if I look out on a vertical standpoint, which verticals your thinking outperform that bar versus underperformed that bar?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes, I don't think we're going to try to do that. I mean, obviously, there are a number of various different scenarios as we move through the year where we will see strong demand some cases of others. We set our guidance based on a number of different potential outcomes, but I'm not going to go and try and lay out a single case here.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Ittai. We'll try to do our best going forward. But as you know, some of these verticals are very lumpy. For example, we may do very well in one quarter with service provider or really well in enterprise if we win a large number of enterprise customers.
So in general, all of them are doing well and contributing double digits in terms of segments. So we hope they all have the possibility of growing --
Ittai Kidron -- Oppenheimer & Company -- Analyst
Got it. Can you give a little bit of an update on how enterprise is going for you, as that's important kind of for the future?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes -- no, I think clearly, it was our No. 2 vertical in Q1. And we tend to pull out enterprise from financials. But if you added the financials, would have been pretty close to our No.
1 vertical. I would say we continue to do very, very well in the enterprise. Customers are incredibly frustrated and seeking an alternative both for quality and innovation reasons. The size of enterprise opportunities always starts small.
And there is a long testing period, but we're pleased with our performance. And our customer gain in Q1 was very strong just like it was in Q3 and Q4 last year.
Ittai Kidron -- Oppenheimer & Company -- Analyst
Very good. Good luck.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Ittai.
Operator
Your next question comes from Mark Moskowitz with Barclays. Your line is open.
Mark Moskowitz -- Barclays -- Analyst
Yes. Thank you. Good afternoon. I just wanted to see if you could touch on where we are in the 100-gig cycle? It seems to be a question we get a lot from investors in terms of Arista's primal-mover or first-mover advantage there.
Are we in the third inning, the fourth inning? Sorry to use a baseball analogy, but how should we think about Arista's momentum with respect to 100 gig?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, if you use the cricket analogy, we're not even in the first innings. But if you use the baseball analogy, I would say we're still between the first and second innings. I think 100-gig is going to prove a very strong requirement not only because we were the first mover last year, but we'll continue to be the first mover for many forms and flavors of it. It's important to understand it's not one product.
It's going to permeate the entire cloud networking. And as we'll start to move more 25 gig and 50 gig into the downlinks with the storage and compute, the need for 100 gigi moves into the spine, into the data center interconnect, into the routing flavors. And so we continue to believe that we'll have large share and build upon our first-mover advantage. And we also believe that the arrival of 400 gig next year will only make us stronger at 100 gig.
So the two will go in tandem.
Mark Moskowitz -- Barclays -- Analyst
Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Mark.
Operator
Your next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Wells Fargo. Your line is open.
Aaron Rakers -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
Yes. Thanks for taking the question. I just want to go on the gross-margin line and understand, I think, this quarter, looking at the guidance of 62% to 64%, that would compare to 63% to 65% guidance ranges over the next last couple of quarters. It looks like your product gross margin came down a little bit.
So just curious of kind of what's changing there? If there is anything within the mix or assumptions there that resulted in a little bit of a lower gross margin assumption?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes, I mean, I think the biggest driver still for our gross margin is kind of within that 63% to 65% range is gonna be customer mix, right? As we head into Q2, we believe we will have a heavier cloud large-customer base mix in Q2 and that's causing us to a little bit cautious on the gross margin guide and the gross margin outlook. So it's really a customer mix question. I think the 63% to 65% for the year, we still feel good about.
Aaron Rakers -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you.
Operator
Your next question comes from Hendi Susanto with Gabelli. Your line open.
Hendi Susanto -- Gabelli & Company -- Analyst
Good evening, and thank you for taking my questions. Congrats on seeing strong sales in Q1 and enterprise sales. I have heard market commentaries that despite of strength in Arista's enterprise sales, Arista is still having a low penetration among enterprises? So Jayshree, would you be able to share insight into opportunities, outlook, and the current state of enterprise penetration for both routing and switching?
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
OK. Thanks, Hendi. I would have to agree with you that Arista can improve its penetration in the enterprise. It's a huge opportunity for us and even though we're doing well, we could do even better.
Our penetration is both in switching and routing. So we're not seeing low penetration in either. I think our penetration in switching is stronger than routing because routing, especially for the scale of capability we offer, tends to be favored by the largest service providers and cloud providers. But I would say in general, I would like to see Arista do better, but we're doing very well.
Hendi Susanto -- Gabelli & Company -- Analyst
Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Hendi.
Operator
Your next question comes from Mitch Steves with RBC Capital Markets. Your line is open.
Mitch Steves -- RBC Capital Markets -- Analyst
Hey, guys. Thanks for taking my questions. So just on the gross margin guidance to get back to that a little bit. So given that the cloud vertical is supposed to be kind of the fastest-growing and largest piece, wouldn't we expect the margins to actually increase given the hyperscale guys typically buy the higher-end products? Or I guess what am I missing there in terms of the mix dynamic?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
I mean, if you look historically, the mix factor has tended to be if you have a lot of cloud or large customers, then obviously they have better or more competitive pricing and that tends to drive a lower gross margin.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, just to clarify what Ita said, I couldn't agree more, Mitch. Our cloud gross margins are driven by volume and volumes drive lower prices and therefore, lower gross margins to us. So our cloud titan margin is significantly below the corporate average.
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Right.
Operator
Your next question comes from James Faucette with Morgan Stanley. Your line is open.
James Faucette -- Morgan Stanley -- Analyst
Great. Thank you very much. And I want to just ask about efforts to continue to expand the customer base, both domestically and internationally, kind of the progress you're making there? One of the things that we have been seeing is that there continue to be what appear to be, at least to us, somewhat extended lead times on delivery. But like to hear kind of how you're thinking about that, what the progress has been and how we should think about opportunities going forward.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, James. You may remember I said we hired Manny Rivelo, and the specific goal here especially was to help with international expansion and enterprise. I think we're both investing very well in that and expanding in certain verticals. The M&A vertical is a particularly strong one for us.
We just came out of a strong network broadcasting show. But I think we can do even more in the international theaters. As you can see, our ratios and percentages have changed by 5 to 10 points the last few quarters, but we can do even more. So there is no denying that similar to the last answer I gave, that Arista's opportunity and execution in enterprise can be even stronger.
But as you also know, enterprises are risk-averse and only in the last year, I would say they have started to take Arista seriously. So I'd ask you all to be patient in seeing the results, just as I'm having to be. But having said that, I fully agree that especially some of the high-performance verticals are going to be strong for us. And I expect to see enterprise continue to be a strong vertical for us.
Operator
Your next question comes from Erik Suppiger with JMP. Your line is open.
Erik Suppiger -- JMP Securities -- Analyst
One just point of clarification. Can you update us on the number of routing customers that you had in the quarter? Then secondly, you talked a little bit about the impact of deferred revenues from the deals that you got from that were certified. Can you talk a little bit about what happened to your backlog? Did you have many deals in backlog that were a function of getting qualified? And has the backlog come down now that those deals have been -- now that you are qualified from the software changes?
Ita Brennan -- Chief Financial Officer
Erik, I'll take the last piece first. I mean, we don't disclose backlog, so we're probably not going to get into that. I think the -- our commentary did say that we felt good about momentum in the quarter and we felt good about the demand across the business in the quarter. But I -- but we're not going to actually disclose the backlog numbers.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes. No, I agree with Ita on that. But to answer your question on FlexRoute customers, I think I had told you the year-end number last year was over 200. And rather than giving you quantity numbers, we did do well this quarter, let me just leave it as I think we're going to double this year.
Erik Suppiger -- JMP Securities -- Analyst
Very good. Thank you.
Jayshree Ullal -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Erik.
Operator
Your next question comes from Alex Henderson with Needham. Your line is open.
Alex Henderson -- Needham & Company -- Analyst
Great. Could -- first, I'd like to just clarify. Did you say you expected mid-25%-type growth rate in the remainder of the year? Or did you say that you expected the mid-25%-type growth rate for the full year? I'm not sure I followed the exact language there.
